abstract.p: Salinity stress is a critical global constraint to wheat production, leading to significant yield reductions and deterioration in grain quality, particularly in arid and semi-arid regions such as Iran. The geographical distribution and salinity levels of soil resources vary across different regions of the country. Out of approximately 6.8 million hectares of salt-affected agricultural land in Iran, around 4.3 million hectares are constrained solely by salinity, posing no other major impediments to sustainable crop production. To address this challenge, advanced synthetic hexaploid wheat lines (SHW), created by combining novel and elite genes from tetraploid wheat (Triticum turgidum L.) and wild ancestors of goat grass (Aegilops tauschii), are proposed as high-potential germplasm for enhancing bread wheat (Triticum aestivum L.). SHW can introduce new genes (such as biotic and abiotic stresses) lost during common wheat evolution. However, concerns remain regarding the quality of synthetic wheat compared to conventional varieties. In the context of global warming and the challenges it presents for plant breeders, particularly in the predominantly arid and dry country like Iran, this study investigates such germplasm for the first time in the region. The aim is to evaluate the performance of a large and selected panel of synthetic hexaploid wheat lines (100 lines) alongside common wheat varieties (nine genotypes) focusing on quality traits, grain-related characteristics, and salt tolerance under various environmental conditions under two consecutive growing seasons. Wide variation and high heritability values were observed for most traits, indicating that the synthetic wheat (SHW) panel possesses valuable diversity for improving salt tolerance in wheat, and the expected gain from selection will be high due to the existing variation. The results showed that grain length (LEN), grain width (WID), grain diameter (DIA), 1000 grain weight (TGW), grain yield (GY), and zeleny sedimentation (ZEL) decreased significantly under salt stress conditions. The value of grain yield, LEN, WID, hardness (HARD), sodium carbonate solvent retention capacity (SCSRC), and sucrose solvent retention capacity (SuSRC) was higher for top 10% of SHW compared to common wheat under stress conditions. The results of correlation analysis indicated that grain yield has a negative correlation with protein content (PRO) and rapid mix test (RMT). Our findings suggest that synthetic wheats present a viable option for bread production compared to conventional wheat, owing to their enhanced resilience and productivity under climate change conditions. The result of this study identified superior genotypes suited for various future studies and the development of new salt-tolerance lines with favorable quality. The Solvent Retention Capacity (SRC) method, developed by Slade and Levine in 1994, is a well-recognized tool for predicting the quality of soft wheat. The AACC 56–11.02 (manual SRC profile) and 56–15.01 (automated SRC profile) are standard methods used for accurately measuring SRC values. The SRC methods had a strong potential to differentiate the quality of wheat genotypes. The superior genotypes identified in this study can be directly utilized or introgressed into wheat breeding programs as donor parents to enhance osmotic tolerance in elite germplasm.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Bread wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), also known as common wheat, is an annual, predominantly autogamous species belonging to the Triticeae tribe of the grasses (Poaceae) family. It is an allohexaploid species (2n = 6x = 42), composed of three sub genomes, A, B, and D1. Major wheat-producing countries include China, India, Russia, the USA, and France, both in terms of cultivated area and total production (FAOSTAT, 2024)2. Wheat provides a substantial portion of daily caloric intake in many regions, accounting for 40–50% in Egypt and Turkey and ∼20% in the UK3. According to FAO (2023), the highest wheat consumption is reported in China (18.3%), India (13.7%), the European Union (14%), Russia (5.9%), and the United States (4.1%)2. Iran is one of the leading wheat producers in the Middle East, with an annual wheat production of about 14 million tons, accounting for more than 50% of the total cereal production in the country. Wheat is also a significant source of protein, dietary fibers, B vitamins, minerals, and other phytochemicals in the human nutrition4. Out of approximately 6.8 million hectares of salt-affected agricultural land in Iran, around 4.3 million hectares are constrained solely by salinity, posing no other major impediments to sustainable crop production. However, the remaining 2.5 million hectares suffer from additional limitations such as poor soil properties, topographical challenges, erosion, and shallow groundwater depth, compounding the adverse effects of salinity stress on agricultural productivity2.

Following its domestication in the Fertile Crescent, wheat cultivation expanded globally, adapting to temperate and, to a lesser extent, tropical and subtropical regions5. T. aestivum contains the A and B subgenomes from tetraploid wheat and D genome from Aegilops tauschii. The first hybridization event approximately 800,000 years ago formed wild emmer wheat6. The second polyploidization event involved tetraploid wheat as the female donor and Ae. tauschii as the male donor. Researchers have recently introgressed Ae. tauschii accessions into tetraploid wheat to restore beneficial alleles, particularly those conferring salt tolerance, lost during domestication7. Synthetic hexaploid wheat (SHW) generated from such crosses has demonstrated strong resistance to various stripe rust pathogen (CYR31, CYR32, CYR33, and CYR34), offering new genetic resources for breeding disease-resistance wheat8. SHW lines have been identified as promising germplasm for environments affected by salinity and elevated temperatures, conditions increasingly exacerbated by climate change9,10. Novel allelic variants from SHWs, and synthetic-derived lines (SDLs) have conferred resistance to diverse biotic and abiotic stresses, and improved traits related to flour quality11. Enhanced photosynthetic efficiency12 and yield performance13 under stress have been reported, highlighting the potential of SHW to improve productivity and yield stability under saline conditions.

Abiotic stresses such as salinity, drought, cold, and heat significantly reduce the survival, biomass production, and yield of crops especially in arid and semi-arid regions Like Iran. From a total of 6.8 million hectares of salt-affected agricultural lands in Iran, approximately 4.3 million hectares are Limited solely by salinity, while 2.5 million hectares face additional constraints such as soil degradation and shallow groundwater14. High soil salt concentrations induce osmotic and ionic stresses in plants, leading to nutritional imbalance and oxidative stress, which impede water and nutrient uptake in the root zone15. Therefore, developing high-yielding wheat varieties with tolerance to salinity is critical for future food security. Breeding is considered one of the most effective strategies for improving plant salt tolerance16. Yield under salt stress can be maintained by selecting heritable traits, especially yield components and other yield-related traits. Omrani et al. (2022) identified several wheat lines with improved performance under saline field conditions in Iran, highlighting their potential for breeding programs17. Achieving superior cultivars requires considering both yield and flour quality. Since bread-making quality differs among genotypes, it is essential to evaluate flour composition, performance, and processing functionality along with salt tolerance17. Flour quality is influenced by genetics, agronomic practices, and post-harvest handling18. Among the various evaluation methods, solvent retention capacity (SRC) is a relatively novel and effective technique developed by Slade et al.19which estimates flour functionality based on the swelling behavior of different polymeric flour components. The SRC profile predicts baking and processing qualities and includes four solvents: water (WSRC) for overall water holding capacity, 5% lactic acid (LASRC) for glutenin network elasticity, 5% sodium carbonate (SCSRC) for damaged starch, and 50% Sucrose (SuSRC) for gliadin and pentosane content19. SRC requires minimal flour amounts (< 1 g) and offers rapid, cost-effective analysis18. The gluten-performance-index (GPI), derived from SRC values, summarizes the overall gluten functionality20. Recently, SRC has been applied by several researchers to predict the flour functionality of different kinds of wheat for various uses due to rapid, low-cost and reliable tests13,21–25. Combined with Near-infrared reflectance (NIR) spectroscopy —which allows rapid, nondestructive estimation of protein content, moisture, Zeleny sedimentation, hardness, RMT, and water absorption— SRC and NIR provide a robust platform for high-throughput quality screening25. The NIR technique has been employed to identify the geographical origin of flour27differentiate wheat genotypes based on storage duration28and classify various wheat varieties29.

Given the low genetic diversity in the existing wheat germplasm and the predicted rise in salt occurrences, it is imperative to produce new wheat varieties that are adaptable to stress situations. Since synthetic wheats have a wider genetic foundation than their tetraploid and diploid relatives, several researchers recommend using synthetic wheats to help alleviate the issue. Several SHW have been developed at CIMMYT30 that are available to be tested in different regions under varied environmental conditions to explore their genetic potential in replacing common wheat cultivars31,32. With the advent of the SRC technique, it is now possible to screen large panels of SHW wheat for quality attributes grown under various environmental conditions and select high-yielding genotypes with better bread-baking flour qualities. By integrating Solvent Retention Capacity (SRC) with Near-infrared Reflectance (NIR) technology, researchers can efficiently screen a vast number of samples. This combined approach provides a cost-effective, rapid, and reliable method that requires only small sample sizes, enhancing the precision and efficiency of flour quality assessments. Previous research has not yet investigated the flour quality of Synthetic Hexaploid Wheat (SHW) under salinity stress or compared it with common wheat. Therefore, this study aims to: (1) evaluate flour quality parameters, yield, and salt tolerance in a large panel of SHW lines across stress and non-stress environments; and (2) To identify superior genotypes using univariate and multivariate statistical approaches for future breeding programs targeting salinity-prone regions. To provide a reliable framework for evaluating SHW performance, this study included five widely cultivated Iranian bread wheat cultivars—Qods, Pishtaz, Baharan, Kavir, and Roshan—as well as four Canadian cultivars—AAC Scotia, Carberry, Norwell, and Sable. The Iranian cultivars are well-adapted to arid and semi-arid climates and are known for stable yield and acceptable bread-making qualities. Kavir and Pishtaz, in particular, exhibit relatively better salt tolerance. The Canadian cultivars, especially Carberry and AAC Scotia, are recognized for superior grain quality and disease resistance. However, their performance under Iranian saline field conditions remains underexplored. These control genotypes serve as valuable benchmarks to assess SHW lines in terms of both yield and flour quality.

sec.title: Variation in wheat quality parameters and effects of salt stress
sec.p: In 2021, salt deficit significantly increased water solvent retention capacity (WSRC), while GY, PRO, and lactic acid solvent retention capacity (LASRC) significantly decreased (Table 1). In 2022, PRO increased and LEN, GY, and DIA decreased significantly due to salt stress. In both years, the water deficit led to decrease GY. Grain yield showed a wide range of variations (294 g m−2–759 g m−2 under salt stress and normal conditions, respectively). During 2021, WSRC significantly increased under salt stress conditions, while it was not affected in 2022 (Table 1). Combined analysis of variance showed significant (P < 0.05) effects of the salinity environments for the studied traits (except grain thickness (TIC), grain sphericity coefficient (SPH), moisture (MOI), PRO, water absorbance (WAT), RMT, HARD, WSRC, SCSRC, SuSRC, LASRC and GPI) (Table S1). The effect of genotype was significant (P < 0.01, P < 0.05) for all of the evaluated traits (except LASRC), indicating considerable genotypic variation among the genotypes (Table S1). The range, genotypic coefficients of variation (GCV) and heritability estimations (h2 are presented in Table 1. The GCV ranged from 0.66 (WAT) to 23.21 (GY) in stress conditions (Table 1). The heritability estimations of some traits, including LEN, TGW, PRO, WAT, HARD, WSRC, SCSRC, SuSRC and GPI under normal conditions were higher than salinity stress conditions, and the remaining traits (including WID, TIC, DIA, SPH, GY, MOI, ZEL, RMT, and LASRC) were higher under salinity stress conditions. The range of broad sense heritability was from 12.76 (MOI) to 73.58 (LEN). conditions (Table 1). The heritability of grain yield was moderate (54.64). The mean performance of TIC, SPH, PRO, RMT, MOI, HARD, WAT, WSRC, SCSRC, SuSRC, LASRC and GPI was not affected under normal and salinity stress conditions for two consecutive years (Table 1). Based on the average of two years, LEN, WID, DIA, TGW, GY, and ZEL significant decreased under salinity stress conditions.

sec.title: Comparison of synthetic and common wheats
sec.p: In normal conditions between SHW and normal wheats (Iranian and foreign), for the characteristics of LEN, WID, TIC, DIA, SPH, PRO, MOI, ZEL, HARD, RMT and traits related to SRC, no difference was observed. Under salt stress conditions, no difference was observed between SHW and normal wheat (Iranian and foreign) for traits WID, TIC, SPH, GY, MOI, WAT, HARD, RMT and SRC-related traits. The amount of LEN, DIA, TGW and ZEL for SHW and common Iranian wheats were more than foreign common wheats under salt stress conditions (Table 2).

sec.title: Association of traits and screening of genotypes
sec.p: Phenotypic correlations between different traits based on the average of all genotypes in two years (Table 4) showed that GY had significant and negative correlations with PRO, RMT, and WAT under normal conditions. Correlations were significant under salt stress conditions for PRO with ZEL, HARD, RMT, and SRC-related traits, while there was a positive and significant correlation of PRO with NIR-related traits (ZEL, HARD, RMT, and WAT) in normal conditions (Table 4). Furthermore, the results showed positive correlations amongst GY with HARD under salt stress conditions while, GY had a positive and significant correlation with SuSRC and MOI under normal conditions.

sec.p: Under both conditions, SRC-related traits had significant and positive associations with each other except SuSRC with LASRC under normal conditions (Table 4). Significant positive relationships were observed between HARD, with ZEL, PRO, and RMT under both conditions. Also, RMT showed significant and positive correlations with ZEL, and PRO under both conditions.

sec.p: Based on grain yield, quality, and salt tolerance indices, a multivariate technique (i.e., PCA) was carried out for normal and salinity stress conditions to understand the correlation between genotypes and traits (Fig. 3). Based on the PC graph, the sum of the first two components explained 54.69% and 49.41% of variation under normal and salinity stress conditions, respectively. The graphs revealed that the measured traits were divided into four groups in normal conditions, separately. The first group included SRC-related traits (WSRC, SCSRC, and SuSRC) except LASRC, the second group contained NIR (except MOI) and its components with LASRC, the third group included physical grain traits (LEN, WID, TIC, DIA, SPH, and TGW) and finally the fourth group included GY, and MOI. The graphs showed that the measured traits were divided into four groups in salinity stress conditions, separately. The first group included SRC-related traits (WSRC, SCSRC, and LASRC) except SuSRC, and NIR. The second group contained physical grain (LEN, WID, TIC, DIA, SPH, and TGW) traits. The third group included GY, and MOI traits, and finally the fourth group included SuSRC. The results showed that SRC-related traits had a strong and positive correlation and were strongly associated with high PC1 under both normal and salt stress conditions, except SuSRC in salt stress conditions. As PC1 had a higher correlation with quality-related traits, it may be considered as “quality” factor (Fig. 3). The principal component analysis showed that genotypes 172, 12, 82, 42, 157, 181, 178, 55, 52, 183, 174, 118, 58, 73, and 199 had higher values of SRC-related traits, and low percent change under normal conditions. Genotypes 29, 63, 5, 74, 65, 199, 48, 55, 52, 68, 2, and 185 had higher values of quality traits, and low percent change (SRC-related traits) under salt stress conditions. For yield-related traits, genotypes 25, 54, 53, 7, 35, 2, 161, 33, and 17 for normal conditions and 71, 167, 178, 72, 181, 142, 166, 88, and 170 for salinity stress conditions had higher values. Box plots showing the distribution of standardized trait values across synthetic hexaploid wheat genotypes under normal and salt stress conditions is presented in Fig. 4.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Evaluating the quality of wheat for end-use is a crucial objective for plant breeders in order to fulfill the food requirements of the increasing global population. Due to salt as one of the significant production constraints in recent years, developing new varieties adapted to new environments is prerequisite. Since wheat germplasm has gone through a genetic bottleneck during its evolution and plant breeding efforts, synthetic hexaploid wheat (SHW) has been proposed as an alternative to broaden the genetic diversity of common wheat. Till now, the grain quality of SHW and its tolerance to abiotic stresses have been neglected. The present study assessed the main flour functional properties, grain yield, and salt tolerance indices of synthetic and common wheat genotypes, therefore, the superior SHW genotypes were introduced.

In this study, the observation of considerable genetic variations (high genotypic coefficient of variation and heritability) for all of the measured traits revealed the high potential of SHW genotypes for improving these traits in genetic programs. The heritability of most variables was categorized as high according to the classification of Dabholkar (1992), especially under salinity stress conditions29. This result was in line with previous research on wheat species that estimated high heritability for most studied traits under both water conditions33. It was suggested that the high heritability of most traits emphasized the presence of some major genes or QTLs affecting them25.

In the present study, the salt deficit affected most of the evaluated traits by increasing or decreasing them. As expected, the effect of salinity stress led to reduce grain yield by 49.77% compared to the normal condition. Salinity stress causes osmotic stress and ion toxicity, through increasing the assimilation of Na+ ion and decreasing K+ within the plant roots. Further, these ionic imbalance affects the uptake, and transport of other important essential ions in target cells and hamper the crucial plant processes and functions34. The ability of synthetic wheat to relocate metabolites is quicker from leaves and stems to fill the grain compared to common wheat under salt stress35. High variation and different responses to salinity stress within the germplasm and between synthetic, and common wheat might propose that selection for adaptive and suitable genotypes is possible for salt tolerance in this germplasm.

The solvent retention content (SRC) method is a relatively new and unique method to measure flour functionality based on the swelling behavior of polymeric flour component networks. The results showed a wide range of variation in the value of SRC-related traits in the big panel of synthetic wheat under salt stress conditions. ZEL varied between 29 and 63, which revealed that all the evaluated SHW flours in this study could have a bread-making potential, according to Duyvejonck et al. (2011), owing to their ZEL values above 20 ml13. Measuring water absorbance (WAT) is a primary responsibility of bakers to improve flour dough handling and to facilitate the preparation of bakery products36. Given that the majority of the lines within this germplasm exhibit significant tolerance to both drought, and salinity, there are no constraints on bread quality when selecting new wheat varieties for areas impacted by climate change.

Comparison among top 10% synthetic hexaploid wheat and common wheat revealed that DIA, TGW, GY, MOI, WAT, WSRC, and, LASRC were almost the same in SHW and common wheat under both (normal and salt) conditions. The LASRC, SCSRC, SuSRC, and WSRC values are explicitly related to the glutenin content, amount of damaged starch, available pentosan, and overall water-holding capacity, respectively13,20,37,38. Good gluten strength, high water absorption, damaged starch, and arabinoxylans are the properties of good bread flour. In contrast, good flour generally has low water absorption, minimal gluten strength, low damaged starch, and arabinoxylans for cookies. The results indicated values of LASRC, and WSRC were the same in SHW and common at normal and salinity stress conditions, while the values of SCSRC, and SuSRC were higher in SHW SHW revealed the better flour quality compared to common wheats due to higher amount of damaged starch, and available pentosane (higher SCSRC, and SuSRC) under salt stress conditions. Given the fact that SHW wheats have demonstrated superior productivity and salt tolerance compared to common wheats, it is reasonable to view SHW-DL wheats as a significant substitute for current bread varieties.

Determining the interrelationship between traits could lead to effective criteria for indirect selection. The correlation of simple traits, which are linked to essential traits is a valuable and conclusive parameter for improving complex traits such as yield, and quality traits. Grain yield, and quality (the important traits) usually have low heritability, which resulted in a lower chance for improving these traits through phenotypic selection. Therefore, improving simultaneous selection for grain yield, and quality has been one of the constant challenges in agriculture. There were negative and significant correlations between protein, and grain yield under normal and salinity stress conditions. In this case, it could be suggested that the genotypes with high grain yield had lower protein content which is in agreement with previous researches24,25. Moreover, the significant and positive relationship between ZEL with HARD under both salinity stress and normal conditions suggested that selection for high ZEL, and PRO can indirectly improve the grain wheat quality for bread-making. These results were consistent with those recently reported in different species of wheat and triticale23,24. Significant and positive correlations of protein with HARD, WAT, ZEL, and RMT (NIR-related traits) showed that more grain protein results in better quality and hardiness. Grain hardness is a significant determinant of wheat products, with hard grain primarily used for bread-making39. On the other hand, the positive correlations of HARD with SRC-related traits only in one conditions showed that the harder genotypes had higher pentosan, and therefore were suitable for bread-making. Generally, soft wheat products such as cookies and crackers require flours with low water absorption. In contrast, hard wheat products like bread require flours with high water absorption. These factors suggest that pentosane plays a detrimental role in the production of cookies and crackers40 but a beneficial role in bread-making indicating that any increase in the protein, water absorbance, grain hardness, and the grain size may be associated with an increase in the amount of flour gliadin. All of the SRC traits were grouped close in PCA, indicating a positive correlation between these SRC variables. These results were in line with earlier studies that also observed strong correlations between these SRC values25,41. All these variables indicated the flour water holding capacity. Genotypes were identified using quality-related traits (SRC), productivity, and protein. Genotypes 1, 4, 52, 23, 7, 53, 159, 73, 142, and 196 revealed higher rank due to quality and grain yield under normal conditions. Genotypes 196, 137, 159, 4, 7, 2, 144, Qods, Kavir, 30, 24, and 8 were introduced as high flour quality, especially SRCs under salinity stress conditions. These synthetic hexaploid wheat-derived lines can also directly or indirectly be used as superior genotypes in wheat breeding programs.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In conclusion, observing high genetic variation for all measured traits revealed that the studied synthetic wheat population constitutes functional genetic variability for quality traits besides productivity, and salt tolerance. These results are expected to be useful in the future wheat breeding program to solve problems will be encountered due to global environmental changes. The superiority of selected lines of SHW was attributed to higher seed yield, amount of damaged starch, and available pentosane under salinity stress and suitability for bread-baking compared to common wheat. Moreover, these results showed that the SRC, as a new and fast approach for assessment of quality, could differentiate and highlight the quality of SHW genotypes. The findings have significant implications for breeding the quality of wheat varieties using SHW as genetic resources to cope with the genetic bottleneck. Superior genotypes were introduced for future studies. The selected wheat genotypes can be recommended as promising lines for salinity-affected areas. These lines can be utilized through appropriate selection as donor parents in wheat breeding programs for further improvement of wheat germplasm for soil salinity tolerance.

sec.title: Plant material and experimental site
sec.p: The plant genetic material used in this study was 109 wheat accessions including 100 synthetic hexaploid wheat lines selected from large panel (produced in the gene bank of the International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT)) along with nine bread wheat cultivars (four Canadian: AAC Scotia, Carbery, Norwell, Sable and five Iranian: Pishtaz, Roshan, Kavir, Baharan, Qods) as control under two different environments of normal and salt stress (Table S3). Twenty three primary SHWs were produced from the original crossings, which used 19 distinct Ae. tauschii and 13 distinct tetraploid accessions (see Table S4). At least one elite hexaploid wheat cross has been made in the panel of synthetic lines, producing varying degrees of synthetic genetic material. The second-degree synthetics (primary SHW crossed to one common hexaploid line) and fifth-degree synthetics (primary synthetic crossed to four common hexaploid lines) are the results of this cross.

sec.title: Growth conditions and treatments
sec.p: The experiments were performed during two winter cropping seasons (October to June of 2021 and 2022) at the Research Farm of Isfahan University of Technology in Najaf Abad, Iran (32° 30́ N, 50° 20́ E). The basic 11 × 11 lattice square design was applied with two repetitions and included additional genotypes as fillers. Planting rows were 2 m long with a spacing of 20 cm (three rows), leading to a seeding density of 300 seeds per square meter according to previous research. During both consecutive years, four replications of the experiments were divided into two condition (normal and stress). No diseases or pests were observed during the plant growth period, and field conditions remained uniform throughout. The site has a silty clay loam soil with pH = 8.3. The soil was calcareous, containing 390 g kg–1Ca-carbonate equivalent, 4.0 g kg–1 organic C, and 0.77 g kg–1 total N, with pH 8.3. The soil was non-saline and non-sodic. The analysis of field soil related to two growing seasons (Oct-Jun), 2021–2022, are shown in Table S5. Based on annual averages of long-term climatic data, the mean annual temperature and precipitation of the station were 14.5̊ C and 140 mm, respectively. The trend of temperature and humidity of Najaf Abad during the growing season (Oct-Jun) of 2021–2022 is depicted in Fig S1. A 50% FC irrigation was maintained until maturity for both treatments42. Soil moisture was measured by standard gravimetric methods43 at depths of 0–30 and 30–60 cm using TDR.

In the saline experiment, freshwater was used until three weeks after plant establishment, at which point saline water was introduced. To prevent plant shock, irrigation was carried out in four stages, with salinity levels of 8, 12, 16, and 20 (dS m−1). Once the desired final salinity of 20 (dS m−1) was reached, all subsequent irrigations were performed at this level until maturity. Identical irrigation volumes, monitored by flow meters (each volume equal to 260 m³/ha), were applied to both saline and non-saline experimental plots. For the saline treatment, dissolved sodium chloride (NaCl) was added from a (150 L) NaCl supply tank into the irrigation water to maintain the target electrical conductivity (EC) of 20 (dS m−1), using calibrated flow meters.

To evaluate the effect of saline irrigation on soil EC, soil samples were collected periodically (from all plots at depths of 0 to 40 centimeters), starting at planting and then weekly until harvest. In the first year of cultivation, the salinity in the saline environment increased to 14 (dS m−1), and in the second year, it rose to 16 (dS m−1). The difference in salinity between the irrigation water and the soil is attributed to the soil’s buffering capacity, as the field soil initially had an average EC of 4 (dS m−1) before saline irrigation.

sec.title: Measurement of traits
sec.p: The SRC values were analyzed in duplicate, with a small coefficient of variation of less than 5% between replicates.
Thousand seed weight (TGW g) was measured using a seed counter, then evaluate seed yield (GY g/m2) after seed harvesting.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: Using Statistical Analysis System (SAS) software (Version 9.4, SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA, https://www.sas.com), the Q-Q plot normality test was carried out to confirm that the residues had a normal distribution before the ANOVA analysis. The data were analyzed separately following the lattice procedure of SAS 9.440 software46. An analysis of variance (ANOVA) was conducted to partition the variation into components in SAS 9.440 software with the least significant difference (LSD) value at the 5% probability level. The least significant difference (LSD) value was computed at the 5% probability level if the F value in the ANOVA was significant. Using PROC CORR in SAS software, the yield and quality attributes’ Pearson’s correlation coefficients (r) were determined independently for the normal and salinity stress treatments. Principal component analysis (PCA) were used to simplify genotype selection and minimize data dimensions based on a correlation matrix built over all replicate data. PCA bi-plots were drawn independently for normal and salt stress conditions to illustrate the associations between the genotypes under study based on recorded traits. The SIIG method47 was used for ranking the selection of genotypes based on a group of correlated traits. For both SRC traits and NIR traits, a SIIG index was created to summarize all traits into a single index, thus facilitating the selection process.
Genetic coefficient of variation (GCV) and heritability was calculated based on the previous researches47.
